senses.de: A person who gives financial or other support to a person, organization, cause, or activity.
senses.ex: He is a well-known patron of the arts.

Tips.title: Cultural Support
Tips.description: Used for someone who upholds the arts or charitable causes through financial help or influence.
Tips.example: Thanks to the patron, the exhibition was a success.

Tips.title: Honorific Title
Tips.description: Often a term of respect, implying the person's generosity or contribution is well-recognized.
Tips.example: She was named patron of the new art gallery.

Tips.title: Not Always Fiscal
Tips.description: Support can be in forms other than money, such as advice or presence at events.
Tips.example: His role as a patron involved advising young artists.

senses.de: A regular customer of a store or business, especially a restaurant or bar.
senses.ex: The pub was filled with its regular patrons.

Tips.title: Business Loyalty
Tips.description: Emphasizes consistent support to a particular business, indicating loyalty and habit.
Tips.example: Being a patron for years, he knew the menu by heart.

Tips.title: Sense of Community
Tips.description: Can suggest a personal connection to the place, a sense of belonging.
Tips.example: Local patrons are the heart of our café.

senses.de: A person who protects or guides a smaller or less experienced person.
senses.ex: A teacher can be seen as a patron for their students.

Tips.title: Guidance Not Control
Tips.description: Indicates a protective figure who advises, but doesn't control the less experienced person.
Tips.example: As a patron, he helped me navigate my first job.

Tips.title: Emotional Support
Tips.description: Can also offer encouragement and moral support in addition to guidance.
Tips.example: Her mentor was also her patron during tough times.

senses.de: In the Catholic Church, a saint who is believed to give special help to a particular place or type of person.
senses.ex: Saint Patrick is the patron saint of Ireland.

Tips.title: Religious Guardian
Tips.description: Reflects a spiritual protector linked to specific groups or causes.
Tips.example: Saint Christopher is the patron saint of travelers.

Tips.title: Historic Connections
Tips.description: Often pertains to a historical context or long-standing tradition in Catholic communities.
Tips.example: Each year, they celebrate their patron saint with a parade.

Advocate.wordDefinition:
Advocate means a person who supports or speaks in favor of something or someone. For example, a lawyer can be an advocate for their client in court.

An advocate speaks up for something or someone, while a patron supports them financially or with their influence.

Backer.wordDefinition:
A backer is someone who supports a particular project or idea financially or with their influence. They may invest money in a business or help fund a creative project.

So, while both backer and patron involve providing financial support, a backer tends to support commercial or entrepreneurial projects, while a patron supports artistic or cultural endeavors.

Benefactor.wordDefinition:
A benefactor is someone who provides help or assistance to others, often in the form of money or resources. For example, a person who donates money to a charity is a benefactor.

Both words refer to people who provide financial support, but benefactors tend to be more focused on helping those in need, while patrons tend to focus on supporting a particular artistic or cultural institution.

Contributor.wordDefinition:
A contributor is someone who gives money, time, or effort towards a cause or project. They are typically viewed as a supporter or helper, rather than someone who is financially invested in the cause or project.

For example, someone who volunteers at a homeless shelter or donates a small sum of money to a charity can be considered a contributor.

In simpler terms, a contributor is someone who helps out, while a patron is someone who provides financial support for a specific cause, often in the arts or culture.

Donor.wordDefinition:
A donor is someone who gives money or donates something to a cause or organization. They typically make a one-time or occasional contribution.

They provide ongoing support to help the person continue their work. Donors are applicable in charity and fundraising while patrons are applicable in the arts and cultural world.

Protector.wordDefinition:
A protector is someone who ensures the safety and well-being of another person or group. For example, a bodyguard can be called a protector of their client.

A patron provides financial support, while a protector provides physical safety.

Sponsor.wordDefinition:
Both the words patron and sponsor imply support, but they are used in different contexts.

A sponsor is a person or company that supports an event, team, or individual with financial aid, exposure, or promotional backing.

Sponsors support sports teams, cultural events, concerts, and other similar events. They receive recognition and exposure through the sponsored event.

A patron supports artists or a charitable organization, whereas a sponsor supports events, teams or an individual.

Supporter.wordDefinition:
A supporter is someone who helps a cause or an idea, without necessarily giving money. They may volunteer their time or advocate on behalf of the cause.

Both terms are applicable in different contexts, but a patron is typically associated with financial support of the arts, while a supporter can help any organization or cause.

quotes.Text: I am a regular, if not exactly enthusiastic, patron of my local bookshop. I try to buy at least some books there because I cling to the belief that it's important to maintain those businesses which put a human face on the exchange of money for goods and services.
quotes.Title: English Author
quotes.Name: Will Self

quotes.Text: Most of the e-mails I get nowadays are from students who ask me how I got my start. In truth it's from having a really supportive family but also having a good patron who will help you - like financing all those early trips I took.
quotes.Title: American Photographer
quotes.Name: Ryan McGinley

quotes.Text: Movies are my religion and God is my patron. I'm lucky enough to be in the position where I don't make movies to pay for my pool. When I make a movie, I want it to be everything to me; like I would die for it.
quotes.Title: American Director
quotes.Name: Quentin Tarantino

quotes.Text: The life of a man who deliberately runs through his fortune often becomes a business speculation; his friends, his pleasures, patrons, and acquaintances are his capital.
quotes.Title: French Novelist
quotes.Name: Honore de Balzac

quotes.Text: If a patron buys from an artist who needs money, the patron then makes himself equal to the artist; he is building art into the world; he creates.
quotes.Title: American Poet
quotes.Name: Ezra Pound

quotes.Text: Tennyson seems to be the patron saint of the wishy washies, which is perhaps why I admire him so much, not only as a poet, but as a man.
quotes.Title: English Writer
quotes.Name: A. N. Wilson

quotes.Text: NARA must provide security at our facilities to protect our public patrons, our staff, and our holdings.
quotes.Title: American Public Servant
quotes.Name: Allen Weinstein

quotes.Text: I cannot live under pressures from patrons, let alone paint.
quotes.Title: Italian Artist
quotes.Name: Michelangelo

quotes.Text: Monsters are the patron saints of imperfection.
quotes.Title: Mexican Director
quotes.Name: Guillermo del Toro

quotes.Text: I want to be like the patron saint of reality.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Fiona Apple
